title: Improved regularity for minimizing capillary hypersurfaces

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We give improved estimates for the size of the singular set of minimizing capillary hypersurfaces: the singular set is always of codimension at least 4, and this estimate improves if the capillary angle is close to $0, \frac{\pi}{2}$, or $\pi$. For capillary angles that are close to 0 or $\pi$, our analysis is based on a rigorous connection between the capillary problem and the one-phase Bernoulli problem.


Keywords. Capillary hypersurfaces, Regularity, One-phase Bernoulli problem.

## 1. INTRODUCTION

Given a smooth Riemannian $(n+1)$-manifold with boundary $\left(X^{n+1}, h\right)$, functions $\sigma \in$ $C^{1}(\partial X)$ satisfying $\sigma \in(-1,1)$ and $g \in C^{1}(X)$, and an open subset $E \subset X$, the Gauss' free energy is

$$
\mathscr{A}(E)=\mathscr{H}^{n}\left(\partial^{*} E \cap \hat{X}\right)-\int_{\partial^{*} E \cap \partial X} \sigma(x) d \mathscr{H}^{n}+\int_{E} g(x) d x
$$

Stationary points (subject to a volume contraint) to the Gauss' free energy model the equilibrium state of incompressible fluids. Indeed, letting $X$ be the container and $E$ the portion of the fluid, the three terms in (1.1) represent the free surface energy (proportional

to area of the separating surface), the wetting energy (modeling the adhesion of the fluid with the wall of the container), and the gravitational energy, respectively. The interface, $M=\partial E \cap \hat{X}$, is usually called a capillary surface. Formally, if $E$ is a stationary point of $\mathscr{A}$, then the capillary surface $M$ should have prescribed mean curvature $g$ and boundary contact angle $\cos ^{-1}(\sigma)$. However, it is well-known that minimizers of $\mathscr{A}$ may have a singular set. The main result of this paper gives improved bounds for the size of this singular set.

Theorem 1.1. There exist $\varepsilon_{0}, \varepsilon_{1}>0$ such that the following holds. Let $\left(X^{n+1}, h\right)$ be a smooth manifold with boundary, $\sigma \in C^{1}(\partial X),-1<\sigma<1$, and $g \in C^{1}(X)$. Suppose that $E \subset X$ is a Caccioppoli set that minimizes (1.1). Then $M=\operatorname{spt}(\partial E \cap \hat{X})$ is a smooth hypersurface of $M$ away from a closed set $\operatorname{sing}(M)$.
(1) We always have that $\operatorname{dim}(\operatorname{sing}(M) \cap \partial X) \leqslant n-4$;
(2) Let $S_{1}=\left\{x \in \partial X: \sigma(x) \in\left(-1,-1+\varepsilon_{0}\right) \cup\left(1-\varepsilon_{0}, 1\right)\right\}$. Then

$$
\operatorname{dim}\left(\operatorname{sing}(M) \cap S_{1}\right) \leqslant n-5
$$

(3) Let $S_{2}=\left\{x \in \partial X: \sigma(x) \in\left(-\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{1}\right)\right\}$. Then

$$
\operatorname{dim}\left(\operatorname{sing}(M) \cap S_{2}\right) \leqslant n-7
$$

Previously, the best known partial regularity, $\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{sing}(M) \leqslant n-3$, was proven by Taylor in [26]. This was extended to the anisotropic case (extending the free surface energy to an elliptic integral depending on the surface unit normal) by De Philippis-Maggi in [10]. When $\theta=\frac{\pi}{2}$, the surface $M$ is usually called a free-boundary minimal surface, and satisfies the sharp estimate $\operatorname{dim} \operatorname{sing}(M) \leqslant n-7$ by Grüter-Jost [16]. Capillary surfaces have shown potential applications in comparison geometry (see, e.g. [19, 20]), where a major stumbling block was the lack a satisfactory boundary regularity in the form of Theorem 1.1.

By the $\varepsilon$-regularity and compactness theorems due to De Philippis-Maggi [10], the monotonicity formula of Kagaya-Tonegawa [18] (see also [9]), and Federer's dimension reduction, Theorem 1.1 follows from the classification of capillary minimizing cones with an isolated singularity. Thus, for every open set $U \subset \mathbf{R}^{n+1}$, let us consider the functional (recall that $\cos \theta=\sigma$ by the first variation)

$$
\mathscr{A}_{U}^{\theta}(\Omega)=\left|\partial^{*} \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \cap U\right|-\cos \theta\left|\partial^{*} \Omega \cap \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \cap U\right|
$$

We denote $\mathscr{A}_{\mathbf{R}^{n+1}}^{\theta}$ simply by $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$, where $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}=\left\{x_{1}>0\right\}$ is an open half space. We say that a Cacciopolli set $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ minimizes $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$, if for every pre-compact open set $U \subset \mathbf{R}^{n+1}$,

$$
\mathscr{A}_{U}^{\theta}(\Omega) \leqslant \mathscr{A}_{U}^{\theta}\left(\Omega^{\prime}\right)
$$

for every Cacciopolli set $\Omega^{\prime} \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ such that $\Omega \Delta \Omega^{\prime}$ is compactly contained in $U$.
Theorem 1.1 is thus a consequence of the following classification result for cones.
Theorem 1.2. There exist $\theta_{0}, \theta_{1}>0$ such that the following holds. Let $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ be a minimizing cone for $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ and $M=\partial \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. Assume that $M$ is smooth away from 0 . Suppose one of the following holds:
(1) $n \leqslant 3$;

(2) $n=4, \theta \in\left(0, \theta_{0}\right) \cup\left(\pi-\theta_{0}, \pi\right)$;
(3) $4 \leqslant n \leqslant 6, \theta \in\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta_{1}, \frac{\pi}{2}+\theta_{1}\right)$.

Then $M$ is flat.
Since any $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$-minimizer $\Omega$ gives a $\mathscr{A}^{\pi-\theta}$-minimizer $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \backslash \Omega$, we may, without loss of generality, assume that $\theta \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$. With this in mind, each of the three cases in Theorem 1.2 is treated differently. Case (1) follows from an Almgren-type argument as in [1] by analyzing the stability inequality on the spherical link $\Sigma=M \cap S^{n}(1)$, and a topological classification result for embedded capillary disks analogous to Fraser-Schoen [15] in the freeboundary case. Case (3) is analogous to the previous work by Li-Zhou-Zhu on the stable Bernstein theorem for capillary surfaces [21, Appendix C], which follows from a careful Simons-type computation as in [25], extending the one for stable free-boundary minimal hypersurfaces.
1.1. Relationship with one-phase free boundary problem. The most interesting part of Theorem 1.2 is Case (2), and it relies on a novel application of the connection between the capillary problem and the one-phase Bernoulli free boundary problem. To motivate the discussion, let us assume, for simplicity, that $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}=\left\{x_{1}>0\right\}$, and $M$ is contained in the graph over the $x_{1}$-direction of a Lipschitz function $u$ - i.e. there exists $u \in \operatorname{Lip}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}=\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}\right)$ such that

$$
M=\left\{\left(u\left(x^{\prime}\right), x^{\prime}\right): x^{\prime} \in \mathbf{R}^{n}, u\left(x^{\prime}\right)>0\right\}
$$

here $x^{\prime}=\left(x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n}\right)$. Set $v=\frac{u}{\tan \theta}$. Assuming that $|\operatorname{Lip}(v)|$ is uniformly bounded as $\theta \rightarrow 0$, we compute that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathscr{A}^{\theta}(\Omega) & =\int_{\{u>0\} \subset \mathbf{R}^{n}}\left(\sqrt{1+|D u|^{2}}-\cos \theta 1_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x^{\prime} \\
& =\int_{\{u>0\}}\left(\sqrt{1+\tan ^{2} \theta|D v|^{2}}-\cos \theta 1_{\{v>0\}}\right) d x^{\prime} \\
& =\int_{\{u>0\}}\left((1-\cos \theta) 1_{\{v>0\}}+\frac{1}{2} \tan ^{2} \theta|D v|^{2}+O\left(\theta^{3}\right)\right) d x^{\prime} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \tan ^{2} \theta \int_{\{u>0\}}\left(|D v|^{2}+1_{\{v>0\}}+O(\theta)\right) d x^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, as $\theta \rightarrow 0, v=\frac{u}{\tan \theta}$ should be an one-homogeneous minimizer of the functional

$$
J(v)=\int_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}\left(|D v|^{2}+1_{\{v>0\}}\right) d x^{\prime}
$$

The functional (1.3) is the well-known one-phase Alt-Caffarelli functional, and the above argument shows heuristically that $J$ should be the linearization of $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ as $\theta \rightarrow 0$.

There is a vast literature concerning regularity of minimizers of the Alt-Caffarelli functional; see, for example, [2], [6], [17], [27]. We also refer the readers to the book by CaffarelliSalsa [7] for an excellent expository of the problem. We note that the idea of $J$ being the linearization of $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ is well-known to the experts (see e.g. [4, 14] and [13, Section 5]), but

this seems the first time that the fine approximation (1.2) has been rigorously established and used to deduce geometric consequences.
Theorem 1.3. Let $\theta_{i} \rightarrow 0+, \Omega_{i}$ be a sequence of cones minimizing $\mathscr{A}^{\theta_{i}}$ with an isolated singularity at 0 , and $M_{i}=\partial \Omega_{i} \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. Then for $i$ sufficiently large, $M_{i}$ is contained in the graph of a Lipschitz function $u_{i}$ over $\mathbf{R}^{n}=\partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. Moreover, up to a subsequence, $\left\{\frac{u_{i}}{\tan \theta_{i}}\right\}$ converges in $\left(W_{l o c}^{1,2} \cap C^{\alpha}\right)\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ to an one-homogeneous minimizer $v$ to the Alt-Caffarelli functional J for all $\alpha \in\{0,1\}$, and the free-boundaries $\partial\left\{u_{i}>0\right\} \rightarrow \partial\{v>0\}$ in the local Hausdorff distance.

Therefore a smooth (away from 0 ) capillary cone with small angle has a fine approximation in by 1-homogenous minimizers to $J$. Additionally, in low dimensions (e.g. $n \leqslant 4$ by $\{6,17\}\}$ ), it is known that an one-homogeneous minimizer to (1.3) is $(x \cdot \mathbf{n})_{+}$for some unit vector $\mathbf{n}$. In this case, we show that the improved convergence

$$
\frac{u_{i}}{\tan \theta_{i}} \rightarrow v
$$

holds actually in $C^{2}$ away from the origin. We use this to prove case (2) of Theorem 1.2. More generally, we have the following result.
Theorem 1.4. Let $n \geqslant 2$. Assume that the only one-homogeneous minimizers of $J$ on $\mathbf{R}^{n}$ are given by $(x \cdot \mathbf{n})_{+}$for some unit vector $\mathbf{n}$. Then there exists $\theta_{0}=\theta_{0}(n)>0$, such that any minimizing cone for $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ in $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ with an isolated singularity at 0 is flat.
1.2. Organization. In Section 2 we recall some preliminaries for capillary surfaces, minimal cones in the Euclidean space and the Alt-Caffarelli functional. In Section 3 we prove case (1) of Theorem 1.2. We carry out the rigorous relation between the capillary problem and the one-phase Bernoulli problem in Section 4, and prove case (2) of Theorem 1.2. Finally, we prove case (3) of Theorem 1.2 in Section 5.

# 2. Preliminaries 

2.1. Notation. We take $(X, h)$ to be a smooth Riemannian manifold with boundary, $E \subset X$ an open set with $M=\partial E \subset \hat{X}$ smooth. Let $v$ be the unit normal vector field of $M$ in $E$ that points into $E, \eta$ be the unit normal vector field of $\partial M$ in $M$ that points out of $X, \bar{\eta}$ be the unit normal vector field of $\partial X$ in $X$ that points outward $X, \bar{v}$ be the unit normal vector field of $\partial M$ in $\partial X$ that points into $\partial E \cap \partial X$. Let $S: T_{M} \rightarrow T_{M}$ denote the shape operator defined by $S(Y)=-\nabla_{Y} v$, and $A$ the second fundamental form on $M$ given as $A(Y, Z)=\langle S(Y), Z\rangle=$ $\left\langle\nabla_{Y} Z, v\right\rangle$. Particularly, if $M$ is unit sphere in $\mathbf{R}^{n+1}$ viewed as the boundary of the unit ball $E$ then we have that $S=\mathrm{id}$ and $A=g_{M}$.

We write $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}=\left\{x \in \mathbf{R}^{n+1}: x_{1}>0\right\}, \mathbf{R}^{n}=\partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}=\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$, and let $\pi: \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}$ be the orthogonal projection. Given any set $S$, let $d(x, S)$ be the Euclidean distance from $x$ to $S$. We denote by $B_{r}(S)=\{x: d(x, S)<r\}$. Constants of the form $c$ or $c_{i}$ will always be $\geqslant 1$.
2.2. First and second variation of capillary functional. Say $E$ is stationary for the capillary functional (1.1), if $\left.\frac{d}{d t}\right|_{t=0} \mathscr{A}\left(E_{t}\right) \geqslant 0$ for all variations $E_{t}$. Take $M=\partial E \cap \hat{X}$. The stationary condition is equivalent to

$$
H_{M}=g \text { in } \hat{X}, \quad\langle v, \bar{\eta}\rangle=\cos \theta \text { on } \partial M \cap \partial X
$$

$E$ is stable for (1.1), if $\left.\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}\right|_{t=0} \mathscr{A}\left(E_{t}\right) \geqslant 0$ for all variations $E_{t}$. The stability condition is equivalent to

$$
\int_{M}\left(\left|\nabla_{M} f\right|^{2}-\left(\left|A_{M}\right|^{2}+\operatorname{Ric}(v, v)\right) f^{2}\right) d \mathscr{H}^{n}-\cot \theta \int_{\partial M} A_{M}(\eta, \eta) f^{2} d \mathscr{H}^{n-1} \geqslant 0
$$

for all $f \in C_{0}^{1}(M)$. We refer the readers to [22, Section 1] for the deductions. Particularly, if $X=\mathbf{R}^{n+1}$, then stability gives

$$
\int_{M}\left(\left|\nabla_{M} f\right|^{2}-\left|A_{M}\right|^{2} f^{2}\right) d \mathscr{H}^{n}-\cot \theta \int_{\partial M} A_{M}(\eta, \eta) f^{2} d \mathscr{H}^{n-1} \geqslant 0
$$

We write $L_{M}=\Delta_{M}+\left|A_{M}\right|^{2}$ the Jacobi operator.
We will often work with capillary stable (minimizing) cones $\Omega$ in $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. By definition, $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is stationary and stable (minimizing) for $\mathscr{A}$ in $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. We say $\Omega$ is a smooth cone, if $M=\partial \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is smooth away from the origin.
2.3. The Alt-Caffarelli functional. For an open set $U \subset \mathbf{R}^{n}$ and $u \in W^{1,2}(U)$, write

$$
J_{U}(u)=\int_{U}|D u|^{2}+\chi_{U \cap(u>0)} d x
$$

for the Alt-Caffarelli functional. We will say that $u \in W_{l o c}^{1,2}(U)$ minimizes $J_{U}$ if for every $U^{\prime} \subset \subset U$ and every $w-u \in W_{0}^{1,2}\left(U^{\prime}\right)$ we have $J_{U^{\prime}}(u) \leqslant J_{U^{\prime}}(w)$. If $U=\mathbf{R}^{n}$ we will simply write $J_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}=J$, and call any minimizer of $J_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}$ an entire minimizer of $J$.

We require the following basic fact.
Lemma 2.1. Let $u \in W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ be an entire minimizer of $J$. Then there exists a constant $c_{0}(n)>0$ such that

$$
\frac{1}{c_{0}} d(x, \partial(u>0)) \leqslant u(x) \leqslant d(x, \partial(u>0))
$$

Proof. The lower bound follow from [2, Corollary 3.6], and the sharp upper bound is a consequence of the estimate $|D u| \leqslant 1$ (see, e.g. [17, Section 2.2]).

We will also make important use of the classification of entire minimizers.
Theorem 2.2 ([17]). Assume $n \leqslant 4$. Let $u \in W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ be an entire minimizer of $J$. Then $u=(x \cdot \boldsymbol{n})_{+}$for some unit vector $\boldsymbol{n}$.
Proof. The classification of 1-homogenous minimizers is due to [17]. The same classification holds for entire minimizers that are not a priori 1-homogenous by an obvious blowdown argument and the Weiss monotonicity [28].

# 3. THE CASE $n=3$ 

Proposition 3.1. Suppose $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is a cone, stationary and stable for $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$, and $M=\partial \Omega \cap$ $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. Assume that $M$ has an isolated singularity so that $\Sigma=M \cap S^{n}(1)$ is smooth. Then we have that

$$
\inf _{f \in C^{1}(\Sigma)} \frac{\int_{\Sigma}\left(\left|\nabla_{\Sigma} f\right|^{2}-\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2} f^{2}\right)-\cot \theta \int_{\partial \Sigma} A_{\Sigma}(\eta, \eta) f^{2}}{\int_{\Sigma} f^{2}} \geqslant-\left(\frac{n-2}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

Proof. This follows from [5, Lemma 4.5]. Note that any homogeneous extension of the first eigenfunction with the capillary boundary condition (i.e. $\frac{\partial f}{\partial \eta}=\cot \theta A(\eta, \eta) f$ ) satisfies the same boundary condition.

Proof of Theorem 1.2 when $n=3$. When $n=3$, (3.1) becomes

$$
\int_{\Sigma}\left(\left|\nabla_{\Sigma} f\right|^{2}-\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2} f^{2}\right)-\cot \theta \int_{\partial \Sigma} A_{\Sigma}(\eta, \eta) f^{2} \geqslant-\frac{1}{4} \int_{\Sigma} f^{2}
$$

for every $f \in C^{1}(\Sigma)$. Setting $f=1$ and using the traced Gauss equation to write $\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}=$ $1-K_{\Sigma}+\frac{1}{2}\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}$, we have that

$$
\int_{\Sigma} K_{\Sigma}-\cot \theta \int_{\partial \Sigma} A_{\Sigma}(\eta, \eta) \geqslant \frac{3}{4} \mathscr{H}^{2}(\Sigma)+\frac{1}{2} \int_{\Sigma}\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}
$$

Using [19, (3.8)], one finds that $\cot \theta A_{\Sigma}(\eta, \eta)=-k_{g}$, where $k_{g}$ is the geodesic curvature of $\partial \Sigma$ with respect to the outward unit normal vector field. Thus, the above gives

$$
\frac{3}{4} \mathscr{H}^{2}(\Sigma) \leqslant \int_{\Sigma} K_{\Sigma}+\int_{\partial \Sigma} k_{g}=2 \pi \chi(\Sigma)
$$

In particular, we have that $\chi(\Sigma)>0$ and thus $\Sigma$ is a topological disk.
We then proceed exactly as in [15, Theorem 2.2]. Precisely, let $u: D \rightarrow S_{+}^{n}$ be the proper minimal embedding such that $\Sigma=u(D)$. Take the standard complex coordinates $z=x_{1}+$ $i x_{2}$, and consider the function

$$
\phi(z)=A_{\Sigma}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial z}, \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\right)^{2}
$$

Here $A_{\Sigma}\left(\partial_{z}, \partial_{z}\right)$ is the second fundamental form in these coordinates, given by $A_{\Sigma}\left(\partial_{z}, \partial_{z}\right)=$ $\left\langle\nabla_{d u\left(\partial_{z}\right)} d u\left(\partial_{z}\right), v\right\rangle$. By [15, Theorem 2.2], we have that $\phi$ is a holomorphic function in $D$. Now consider the boundary behavior of $\phi$. For this, take $(r, \theta)$ the polar coordinates on $D$, so that $z=r e^{i \theta}$. Set $w=\log z=\log r+i \theta$. Then $A\left(\partial_{z}, \partial_{z}\right)=\frac{1}{z^{2}} A\left(\partial_{w}, \partial_{w}\right)$. Along $\partial \Sigma$, we have that

$$
d u\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)=\lambda \eta=\lambda(\cos \theta \bar{\eta}+\sin \theta \bar{v}), \quad v=\cos \theta \bar{v}-\sin \theta \bar{\eta}
$$

here $\lambda=\left|d u\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\right)\right|$. Consequently, we conclude that

$$
A_{\Sigma}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}, \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\right)=\lambda\left\langle\nabla_{d u\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\right)}(\cos \theta \bar{\eta}+\sin \theta \bar{v}), \cos \theta \bar{v}-\sin \theta \bar{\eta}\right\rangle=0
$$

because $|\tilde{v}|=|\tilde{\eta}|=1$ and $\partial S_{+}^{n}$ is totally geodesic. Consequently, the same argument as in [15, Theorem 2.2] shows that $z^{4} \phi(z)$ vanishes identically on $D$, and that $\Sigma$ is totally geodesic.

# 4. THE CASE $n=4$ WITH $\theta$ CLOSE TO 0 

In this section, we consider $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ that minimize the functional

$$
\mathscr{A}^{\theta}(\Omega)=\left|\partial^{*} \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}\right|-\cos \theta\left|\partial^{*} \Omega \cap \partial_{+} \mathbf{R}^{n+1}\right|
$$

in $B_{1}$ or (later) in compact subsets of $\mathbf{R}^{n+1}$. Here $\theta \in\left\{0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right\}$. We say $\Omega$ is a smooth minimizer of $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ in $U$ if $M:=\partial \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is a smooth hypersurface in $U$, which extends smoothly up to the solid boundary $\partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$.

Most of our work in this Section is focused on proving the following convergence theorem, which is essentially a generalization/refinement of Theorem 1.3.

Theorem 4.1. Let $\theta_{i} \rightarrow 0+, \Omega_{i}$ be a sequence of minimizers of $\mathscr{A}^{\theta_{i}}$ in $B_{1}$ which are smooth (resp. conical with an isolated singularity at 0 ), and $M_{i}=\partial \Omega_{i} \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. Then for a dimensional constant $\varepsilon(n)$ and $i$ sufficiently large, $M_{i} \cap B_{1 / 2} \cap B_{\varepsilon}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ (resp. $M_{i} \cap B_{1 / 2}$ ) is contained in the graph of a Lipschitz function $u_{i}$ over $B_{1 / 2}^{n} \equiv \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \cap B_{1 / 2}$. Moreover, up to a subsequence, $\theta_{i}^{-1} u_{i}$ converges in $\left(W_{l o c}^{1,2} \cap C_{l o c}^{\alpha}\right)\left(B_{1 / 4}^{n}\right)$ to a minimizer $v$ (resp. one-homogenous minimizer v) to the Alt-Caffarelli functional J for all $\alpha \in(0,1)$, and the free-boundaries $\partial\left\{u_{i}>0\right\} \rightarrow \partial\{v>0\}$ in the local Hausdorff distance in $B_{1 / 4}^{n}$.

If $n \leqslant 4$, then $v$ is entirely regular (resp. linear), and the convergence $\theta_{j}^{-1} u_{i} \rightarrow v$ is $C_{l o c}^{2, \alpha}$ in $B_{1 / 4}^{n}$. Near the free-boundary this is interpreted in the sense of the Hodograph transform.
Remark 4.2. More generally, in Theorem 4.1 (and Lemma 4.14) instead of assuming $n \leqslant 4$ one can assume $n+1 \leqslant k^{*}$, where $k^{*}$ is the smallest dimension in which there is a non-linear 1-homogenous minimizer of $J$ in $\mathbf{R}^{k^{*}}$. The value of $k^{*}$ is not yet known, but by the works of [17], [12], $k^{*} \in\{5,6,7\}$.
4.1. Preliminaries. Our first Lemma says that if the interior surface $M:=\partial \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is smooth (up to the boundary), then in a region uniform far away from the interface $\partial M \cap$ $B_{1} \subset \partial \mathbf{R}^{n+1}, M$ is mass-minimizing in the sense of boundaries.

Lemma 4.3. Let $\Omega$ be a smooth minimizer of $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ in $B_{1}$, and let $M=\partial \Omega \cap B_{1} \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}, E=$ $\Omega \cup\left(\pi^{-1}\left(\partial \Omega \cap \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}\right) \backslash \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}\right)$, and $S=\pi^{-1}\left(\partial M \cap \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \cap B_{1}\right)$. Then

$$
\partial(E] \backslash\left(B_{1} \backslash S\right) \equiv[M]
$$

is a mass-minimizing boundary in $B_{1} \backslash S$.
Proof. By construction we have $\partial E=M$ in $B_{1} \backslash S$. Let $F$ be a Caccioppoli set in $B_{1}$ such that $F \Delta E$ is contained in a compact subset $W$ of $B_{1} \backslash S$. Without loss of generality (by replacing $W$ by a compact set containing it), we can assume that $W=\pi^{-1}\left(W_{0}\right) \cap B_{r}$ for $W_{0} \subset \mathbf{R}^{n}$ and $r<1$. Since $M \equiv \partial \Omega \cap B_{1} \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is a smooth minimal hypersurface and (by the maximum principle) meets $\partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ only at $\partial M$, there is an $\varepsilon>0$ so that

$$
d\left(x, \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}\right) \geqslant 2 \varepsilon \quad \forall x \in \partial \Omega \cap W
$$

Define the piecewise linear map $p_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n+1}\right)=\left(\max \left\{x_{1}, \varepsilon\right\}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n+1}\right)$, and define $F_{\varepsilon}=F \cup\left(\left\{x_{1}>\varepsilon\right\} \cap B_{1}\right)$. We have $\partial^{*} F_{\varepsilon}=p_{\varepsilon}\left(\partial^{*} F\right)$ and $p_{\varepsilon}\left(\partial^{*} F\right) \cap W=p_{\varepsilon}\left(\partial^{*} F \cap W\right)$, and so since $\operatorname{Lip}\left(p_{\varepsilon}\right) \leqslant 1$ we get the inequality $\left|\partial^{*} F_{\varepsilon} \cap W\right| \leqslant\left|\partial^{*} F \cap W\right|$. From (4.1) we have $F_{\varepsilon} \Delta \Omega \subset \subset W \cap\left\{x_{1}>0\right\}$. Therefore if we set $\Omega^{\prime}=F_{\varepsilon} \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ we can make the comparison $\mathscr{A}_{W}^{\theta}(\Omega) \leqslant \mathscr{A}_{W}^{\theta}\left(\Omega^{\prime}\right)$. But since $\partial^{*} \Omega^{\prime} \cap \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}=\partial^{*} \Omega \cap \partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$, we can deduce the inequalities

$$
\left|\partial^{*} E \cap W\right|=\left|\partial^{*} \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \cap W\right| \leqslant\left|\partial^{*} \Omega^{\prime} \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1} \cap W\right|=\left|\partial^{*} F_{\varepsilon} \cap W\right| \leqslant\left|\partial^{*} F \cap W\right|
$$

We next recall the following application of the Allard regularity theorem.
Theorem 4.4. There is an $\varepsilon_{1}(n)$ such that the following holds. Let $T=\partial\{E\}$ be a massminimizing boundary in $B_{r}$ such that

$$
0 \in \operatorname{spt} T, \quad \sup _{\operatorname{spt} T \cap B_{r}} r^{-1}\left|x_{1}\right|<\varepsilon \leqslant \varepsilon_{1}
$$

Then $\operatorname{spt} T \cap B_{r / 2}=\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u)$ for some $C^{2}$ function $u$ with the estimate

$$
r\left|D^{2} u\right|+|D u|+r^{-1}|u| \leqslant c_{1}(n) \varepsilon, \quad \text { in } B_{r / 2}
$$

Proof. The estimate is scaling invariant so we assume $r=1$ without loss of generality. Assume the Proposition fails: then for any predetermined $c(n)$, there exists a sequence of mass-minimizing boundaries $T_{j}=\partial\left\{E_{j}\right\}$ and numbers $\varepsilon_{j} \rightarrow 0$, so that $0 \in \operatorname{spt} T_{j}$ and $\sup _{\operatorname{spt} T_{j} \cap B_{1}}\left|x_{1}\right| \leqslant \varepsilon_{j}$, but $\operatorname{spt} T_{j} \cap B_{1 / 2}$ is not the graph of a $C^{2}$ function over $\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$ satisfying $|u|_{C^{2}} \leqslant c(n) \varepsilon_{j}$.

Passing to a subsequence, by compactness of mass-minimizing boundaries we can assume $E_{j} \rightarrow E$ and $T_{j} \rightarrow T=\partial\{E\}$ for some mass-minimizing boundary $T$. However our contradiction hypothesis implies $0 \in \operatorname{spt} T$ and $\operatorname{spt} T \subset\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$. Therefore we must have $T= \pm \partial\left\{\left\{x_{1}<0\right\}\right\}$, and hence $T_{j} \rightarrow\left\{\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}\right\}$ with multiplicity-one. Allard's them implies that for $j \gg 1$, $\operatorname{spt} T_{j} \cap B_{1 / 2}=\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u)$ with $|u|_{C^{2}} \leqslant c(n) \sup _{\operatorname{spt} T_{j} \cap B_{3 / 4}}\left|x_{1}\right| \leqslant c(n) \varepsilon_{j}$, which is a contradiction.

We recall the Harnack inequality for harmonic functions on mass-minimizing boundaries by Bombieri-Guisti [3].

Theorem 4.5 ([3, Theorem 5]). Let $T=\partial\{E\}$ be a mass-minimizing boundary in $B_{1}^{n+1}$. There are constants $\sigma(n) \in(0,1), c_{2}(n)$ such that if $u \in C^{1}\left(B_{1}\right)$ satisfies

$$
\int \nabla u \cdot \nabla \phi d \mu_{T}=0, \quad \forall \phi \in C_{0}^{1}\left(B_{1}\right), u>0 \text { on } \operatorname{spt} T
$$

then

$$
\sup _{\operatorname{spt} T \cap B_{\sigma}} u \leqslant c_{2} \inf _{T \cap B_{\sigma}} u
$$

Remark 4.6. It would be interesting to prove a version of Theorem 4.5 on the reduced boundary of a capillary minimizer, which holds up to the boundary (cf. [11]). This would simplify the arguments below.

Our final preliminary lemma rules out a minimizer $\Omega$ of $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ having large pieces that stay too close to the boundary.

Lemma 4.7. There is $\varepsilon_{3}(n)>0$ so that the following holds. Let $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ be a minimizer for $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ in $B_{1}$, and $u: B_{1}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ a non-negative Lipschitz function. Suppose either: $\Omega \cap B_{1}=$ $\left\{x \in B_{1}: 0<x_{1}<u(\pi(x))\right\}$ and $\sup _{B_{1 / 2}^{n}} u \leqslant \varepsilon_{3} \theta$; or $\Omega \cap B_{1}=\left\{x \in B_{1}: u(\pi(x))<x_{1}\right\}$ and $\sup _{B_{1 / 2}^{n}} u \leqslant \varepsilon_{3}$. Then $u \equiv 0$ in $B_{1 / 4}^{n}$.

By allowing for $\theta \in(0, \pi)$ in the below proof, and replacing $\Omega$ with $B_{1} \backslash \Omega, \theta$ with $\pi-\theta$ as necesary, there will be no loss of generality in assuming we are in the first case. We loosely follow the ideas of $\{2$, Lemma 3.4$\}$. Let $\phi(r=|x|)$ be the graphing function of the upper half of the standard catenoid, defined on $\left\{x \in \mathbf{R}^{n}:|x|>1\right\}$. Standard estimates (e.g. $\{23\})$ imply that as $r \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\phi(r)= \begin{cases}a \log (r)+O(1) & n=2 \\ b_{n}-d_{n} r^{2-n}+O\left(r^{1-n}\right) & n \geqslant 3\end{cases}
$$

for some constants $a, b_{n}, d_{n}>0$. Choose $\lambda(n, \varepsilon, \theta), \mu(n, \varepsilon, \theta)>0$ (and ensure $\varepsilon(n)$ is small) so that if

$$
v=\max \{\lambda \phi(|x| / \lambda)-\mu, 0\}
$$

then $v(r=1 / 4)=0$ and $v(r=1 / 2)=2 \varepsilon \theta$. We note it then follows from our choice of $\lambda$, the structure of $\phi$ and the smallness of $\varepsilon(n)$ that $\left|\partial_{r} v\right|_{r=1 / 4} \mid \leqslant c(n) \varepsilon \theta$.

The graph of $v$ is a scaled and translated portion of the catenoid. Write $v$ for the unit normal vector of $\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(v)$ such that $v \cdot e_{1}>0$, and extend $v$ to be defined on all of $\mathbf{R}^{n+1}$ so it is constant in the $x_{1}$ direction. A standard computation shows that in $\left\{x \in \mathbf{R}^{n+1}:|\pi(x)| \geqslant\right.$ $1 / 4\}$, the $n$-form $\omega:= \star v$ is a calibration for $\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(v)$. Let us define the hypersurface

$$
S=\left\{x=\left(x_{1}, x^{\prime}\right) \in \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}^{n}:\left|x^{\prime}\right|=1 / 4 \text { and } 0<x_{1}<u\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right\}
$$

endowed with the inward-pointing orientation, and define the cylinder

$$
U=\left\{x=\left(x_{1}, x^{\prime}\right) \in \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}^{n}: u\left(x^{\prime}\right)>v\left(x^{\prime}\right) \text { and } x^{\prime} \in B_{1 / 2}^{n} \backslash B_{1 / 4}^{n}\right\}
$$

so that, because $v>u$ on $\partial B_{1 / 2}^{n}$,

$$
\partial U=\left\{\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u) \cap U\right\}-\left\{\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(v) \cap U\right\}+S
$$

(here we equip the graphs with an orientation so its unit normal vectors point into positive $x_{1}$ direction). Now since $\min (u, v)$ is a Lipschitz function which agrees with $u$ along $\partial B_{1 / 2}^{n}$, we can make the comparison

$$
\mathscr{A}^{\theta}(\Omega) \leqslant \mathscr{A}^{\theta}\left(\left\{0<x_{1}<\min \left(u(\pi(x)), v(\pi(x))\right)\right\}\right)
$$

and thereby compute:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B_{1 / 4}^{n} \cap(u>0]} \sqrt{1+|D u|^{2}}-\cos \theta d x \leqslant \int_{\{u>0\} \cap B_{1 / 2}^{n} \backslash B_{1 / 4}^{n}} \sqrt{1+|D \min (u, v)|^{2}}-\sqrt{1+|D u|^{2}} d x \\
& =\mathscr{H}^{n}\left(\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(v) \cap U\right)-\mathscr{H}^{n}\left(\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u) \cap U\right) \leqslant \int_{\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(v) \cap U} \omega-\int_{\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u) \cap U} \omega
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=\int_{S} \omega=\int_{\partial B_{1 / 4}^{n}} \frac{\partial_{r} v}{\sqrt{1+|D v|^{2}}} u \leqslant c(n) \varepsilon \theta \int_{\partial B_{1 / 4}^{n}} u
$$

On the other hand, we claim we have the estimate

$$
\int_{\partial B_{1 / 4}^{n}} u \leqslant c(n) \theta^{-1} \int_{B_{1 / 4}^{n} \cap(u>0)} \sqrt{1+|D u|^{2}}-\cos \theta d x
$$

Combining (4.2) with (4.3) will give $\int_{\partial B_{1 / 4}^{n}} u=0$ provided $\varepsilon(n)$ is sufficiently small, which by a trivial comparison argument implies $u=0$ on $B_{1 / 4}$.

To prove (4.3), we break into two cases. For $\theta \in[0, \pi / 2]$, we first note that we have the inequalities

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 \sqrt{1+|D u|^{2}}-|D u| \theta-1 & \geqslant \sqrt{4-\theta^{2}}-1 \\
& \geqslant 1-\theta^{2} / 3 \\
& \geqslant 1-\theta^{2} / 2+\theta^{4} / 24 \\
& \geqslant \cos \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

The first inequality follows by considering the minimum of the function $t \mapsto 2 \sqrt{1+t^{2}}-$ $t \theta-1$ on $\{t \geqslant 0\}$; the second and the third hold for $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$ by elementary algebra; the fourth holds by the Taylor remainder theorem.

Now using the trace inequality, then our bound $|u| \leqslant \varepsilon \theta$, and then the above inequality, we can estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\partial B_{1 / 4}^{n}} u & \leqslant c(n) \int_{B_{1 / 4}^{n}}(|D u|+u) d x \\
& \leqslant c(n) \theta^{-1} \int_{\{u>0\} \cap B_{1 / 4}^{n}}(|D u| \theta+1-\cos \theta) d x \\
& \leqslant 2 c(n) \theta^{-1} \int_{\{u>0\} \cap B_{1 / 4}^{n}}\left(\sqrt{1+|D u|^{2}}-\cos \theta\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

This proves the assertion when $\theta \in[0, \pi / 2]$. When $\theta \in[\pi / 2, \pi]$, then we can obtain the last two inequalities by the fact $\cos \theta \leqslant 0$ and the inequality $t+1 \leqslant 2 \sqrt{t^{2}+1}$. This proves the Lemma.
4.2. Inhomogenous blow-up to Alt-Caffarelli. We show here that capillary minimizers of small angle with good a priori estimates near the boundary are graphical, and that the graphing function looks close to a minimizer of the Alt-Caffarelli energy at the scale of the angle. We first prove that non-degeneracy estimates (4.4) near the boundary can be extended to graphical estimates at both near and far from the boundary. In Section 4.3, we shall prove using a bootstrap-type argument that estimates like (4.4) hold in a neighborhood of uniform size.

Lemma 4.8 (Graphical propogation). Given $\gamma>0$, there exists $\theta_{0}, \varepsilon, c$ positive and depending only on $(n, \gamma)$ so that the following holds. for all $x \in M \cap B_{\gamma}(\partial M)$, where $c_{0}$ as in Lemma 2.1.

Proof. Let $\varepsilon_{1}, c_{1}$ be the constants from Theorem 4.4, $\sigma, c_{2}$ be the constants from Theorem 4.5, and $\varepsilon_{3}$ the constant from Lemma 4.7. Define

$$

& M \cap\{\gamma / 4<d(x, \partial M)<\gamma / 2+N \rho\} \cap\left\{0<x_{1}<4 \varepsilon_{1} \rho / c_{2}^{N}\right\} \cap B_{3 / 4} \\

If $M \cap$ $B_{4 \rho}(y) \cap B_{4 \varepsilon_{1} \rho / c_{2}^{N}}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right) \neq \varnothing$, then by Theorem 4.5 (with $u(x)=x_{1}$ ) we must have $M \cap B_{4 \rho}(y) \subset$ $B_{4 \varepsilon_{1} \rho / c_{2}^{N-1}}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$, and hence by Theorem $4.4 M \cap B_{2 \rho}(y)=\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u)$ for some smooth function $u$ satisfying $|u| \leqslant 4 \varepsilon_{1} \rho / c_{2}^{N-1}$.

Using Theorem 4.5 again, we deduce $M \cap B_{2 \rho}(y) \cap B_{4 \varepsilon_{2} \rho / c_{2}^{N}}\left(\mathbf{R}^{n}\right) \subset\left\{\left(\gamma / 8 c_{0}\right) \tan \theta / c_{2}^{N}<x_{1}<2 \gamma c_{2}^{N} \tan \theta\right\}$. Let $M^{\prime}=M \cap\left\{0<x_{1}<\varepsilon\right\}$. Given $y=\left(y_{1}, y^{\prime}\right) \in M^{\prime} \cap B_{3 / 4}$ take $r=\min \left\{d\left(y^{\prime}, \partial M\right) / 16, \rho\right\}$, and note that by (4.4), (4.7), (4.6) we have

$$
y_{1} \leqslant(K / \rho) \tan \theta r \leqslant \frac{\min \left\{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{3}\right\}}{100 c_{1} c_{2}} r \leqslant r / 100
$$

so that in particular we have $y \in M^{\prime} \cap B_{r / 4}\left(y^{\prime}\right)$. By Theorem 4.5, we have $M^{\prime} \cap B_{4 r}\left(y^{\prime}\right) \subset\left\{x_{1}<\right.$ $c_{2}(K / \rho) \tan \theta r\}$, and so by (4.9) and Theorem $4.4 M^{\prime} \cap B_{2 r}\left(y^{\prime}\right)=\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u)$ for $u: B_{r}^{n}\left(y^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow$

$\mathbf{R}$ a smooth function satisfying

$$
r^{-1}|u|+|D u| \leqslant c_{1} c_{2}(K / \rho) \tan \theta
$$

By our choice of $\theta_{0}$, Lemma 4.7 then implies that

$$
\Omega \cap B_{r / 2}\left(y^{\prime}\right)=\left\{x \in B_{r / 2}\left(y^{\prime}\right): 0<x_{1}<u(\pi(x))\right\}
$$

From (4.10), we deduce that $\pi\left(M^{\prime}\right) \cap B_{1 / 2}^{n}$ is an open subset of $\mathbf{R}^{n}$, and $M^{\prime} \cap B_{1 / 2}=$ $\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u) \cap B_{1 / 2}$ for $u: \pi\left(M^{\prime}\right) \cap B_{1 / 2}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ a smooth positive function satisfying

for all $x \in \pi\left(M^{\prime}\right) \cap B_{1 / 2}^{n}$, with $c=c(n, \gamma)$. The upper bounds in (4.12) follow from (4.10), and the lower bound from (4.4), (4.7). By (4.10) and our choice of $\theta_{0}$, we have

$$

and so we can extend $u$ by zero to all of $B_{1 / 2}^{n}$ to obtain a Lipschitz function satisfying the required properties (2), (3), (4), (5).

Finally, we observe that if $\Omega^{\prime}$ is any connected component of $\Omega \cap\left\{0<x_{1}<\varepsilon\right\}$, then by (4.4) necessarily $\partial \Omega^{\prime} \cap\left\{0<x_{1}<\varepsilon\right\} \cap B_{3 / 4}$ is a non-empty subset of $M^{\prime} \cap B_{3 / 4}$. By a trivial modification of the above proof, we also obtain a version of the graphical propogation for smooth cones.

Lemma 4.10 (Graphical propogation for cones). Given $\gamma>0$, there exist $\theta_{0}(n, \gamma), c(n, \gamma)$ so that the following holds. Suppose $\theta \leqslant \theta_{0}$, and $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is a dilation-invariant minimizer for $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}$ which is smooth away from the cone point 0 . Write $M=\partial \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$. Assume that

$$

for all $x \in M \cap B_{\gamma}(\partial M) \cap \partial B_{1}$, where $c_{0}$ as in Lemma 2.1.
Then there exists a 1-homogenous Lipschitz function $u: \mathbf{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ so that:
(1) $\Omega=\left\{x: 0<x_{1}<u(\pi(x))\right\} \mathscr{L}^{n+1}$-a.e.;
(2) $M=\operatorname{graph}_{\mathbf{R}^{n}}(u)$ in $\mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$;

Proof. We first note that by the maximum principle in the sphere $M \cap \partial B_{1}$ is necessarily connected, and by the maximum principle for stationary varifold cones we must have $\partial M \cap \partial B_{1} \neq \varnothing$. to $\mathbf{R}^{n}$ by 1-homgeneity, then (1)-(5) will continue to hold on $\mathbf{R}^{n}$, as the estimates in (4), (5) are invariant under 1-homogenous rescaling.

Proposition 4.11 (Inhomogenous blow-up). Thus we obtain a sequence $x_{\mu} \in \partial\left\{v_{\mu}>0\right\}$ with $x_{\mu} \rightarrow x$. Conversely, suppose we have $x_{\mu} \in \partial\left\{v_{\mu}>0\right\}$ with

$x_{\mu} \rightarrow x \in B_{1 / 2}$. If $x \notin \partial(v>0)$, then there is a ball $B_{2 r}(x)$ on which $v=0$. So we must have $x \in \partial(v>0)$. This proves our claim.

For any fixed $B_{2 r}(p) \subset\{v>0\}$, then $B_{2 r}(p) \subset\left\{v_{\mu}>0\right\}$ for all $\mu \gg 1$. Since each $u_{\mu}$ solves the minimal surface equation in $B_{2 r}(p)$, by standard elliptic estimates $v_{\mu} \rightarrow v$ smoothly in $B_{r}(p)$. So $v_{\mu} \rightarrow v$ smoothly on compact subsets of $B_{1 / 2} \cap\{v>0\}$. Together with the uniform Lipschitz bounds on $v_{\mu}$ and the local Hausdorff convergence $\partial\left\{v_{\mu}>0\right\} \rightarrow \partial(v>0)$, we get $v_{\mu} \rightarrow v$ in $W_{i o c}^{1,2}\left(B_{1 / 2}\right)$.

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\partial \Sigma} f & \leqslant 2 \int_{\partial \Sigma} f\left(-\eta \cdot e_{n+1}\right)=2 \int_{\Sigma} \operatorname{div}_{\Sigma}\left(-f e_{n+1}\right) \\
& =2 \int_{\Sigma} \nabla_{\Sigma} f \cdot\left(-e_{n+1}\right)+f \operatorname{div}_{\Sigma}\left(-e_{n+1}\right) \leqslant 2 \int_{\Sigma}\left|\nabla_{\Sigma} f\right|+(n-1) f
\end{aligned}
$$

having used that $\operatorname{div}_{\Sigma}\left(e_{n+1}\right)=n-1$.

We now take Simons' equation on $\Sigma$ (see $\{25$, Theorem 5.3.1]*),

$$
\Delta_{\Sigma} A_{\Sigma}=\left(n-1-\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}\right) A_{\Sigma}

and inner product with $A_{\Sigma}$ and integrate over $\Sigma$, to obtain

$$
\int_{\Sigma}\left|\nabla_{\Sigma} A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}+\left(n-1-\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}\right)\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}=\int_{\partial \Sigma} \frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}}{\partial \eta}

$$
\left|\frac{\partial\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{2}}{\partial \eta}\right| \leqslant c(n) \cot \theta\left|A_{\Sigma}\right|^{3}
$$

$$

\end{aligned}
$$

having used Kato's inequality $\left|\nabla_{\Sigma}\right| A_{\Sigma}| | \leqslant\left|\nabla_{\Sigma} A_{\Sigma}\right|$ in the last line. Ensuring $\delta(n)$ is small, we deduce $A_{\Sigma} \equiv 0$, as desired.

# 5. THE CASE $4 \leqslant n \leqslant 6$ WITH $\theta$ CLOSE TO $\pi / 2$ 

In this section we prove case (3) of Theorem 1.2. In fact, we prove the following slightly stronger result.

Theorem 5.1. Suppose $4 \leqslant n \leqslant 6$. There exists $\theta_{1}=\theta_{1}(n)$ such that if $\Omega \subset \mathbf{R}^{n+1}$ is a stable minimal cone for $\mathscr{A}^{\theta}, M=\partial \Omega \cap \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is smooth away from 0 , and $\theta \in\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta_{1}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$, then $M$ is flat.

Remark 5.2. It will be clear from the proof that $\theta_{1}$ can be explicitly computed depending on $n$ (compare to $\{21$, Appendix C $\}$ ).

We first recall the following consequence of the Simons's equation on a minimal cone.
Lemma 5.3. Let $M^{n} \subset \mathbf{R}^{n+1}$ be a minimal cone. Then for every $\lambda \in(0,1)$, we have that

$$
\Delta\left(\frac{1}{2}|A|^{2}\right)+|A|^{4} \geqslant 2 \lambda|x|^{-2}|A|^{2}+\left[(1-\lambda)\left(1+\frac{2}{n}\right)+\lambda\right]|\nabla| A \|^{2}
$$

on $M$.
Proof. Fix a point $p \in M$ and take normal coordinates $\left\{x_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{n}$ around $p$, then the Simons equation gives

$$
\Delta\left(\frac{1}{2}|A|^{2}\right)+|A|^{4}=\sum_{i, j, k=1}^{n} A_{i j, k}^{2}
$$

We write the right hand side of the above as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta\left(\frac{1}{2}|A|^{2}\right)+|A|^{4}=\lambda\left(\sum_{i, j, k=1}^{n} A_{i j, k}^{2}-\sum_{i, j, k=1}^{n}|A|^{-2}\left(A_{i j} A_{i j, k}\right)^{2}\right) \\
&+(1-\lambda) \sum A_{i j, k}^{2}+\lambda \sum|A|^{-2}\left(A_{i j} A_{i j, k}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\sum|A|^{-2}\left(A_{i j} A_{i j, k}\right)^{2}=|\nabla| A \|^{2}$. On one hand, since $M$ is a cone, we have that (see $[24, \mathrm{~B} .9])$

$$
\sum_{i, j, k=1}^{n} A_{i j, k}^{2}-\sum_{i, j, k=1}^{n}|A|^{-2}\left(A_{i j} A_{i j, k}\right)^{2} \geqslant 2|x|^{-2}|A(x)|^{2}
$$

On the other hand, we have the following Kato type inequality (see [8, (2.22)]):

$$
\sum A_{i j, k}^{2} \geqslant\left(1+\frac{2}{n}\right)|\nabla| A \|^{2}
$$

(5.1) follows from combining the above two estimates.

Next, we establish the following trace type inequality on $M$. This was proven in [21, Lemma C.3]. We include it here for completeness. (Compare to Lemma 4.15, where a similar trace type inequality holds when $\theta$ is close to 0 ).
Lemma 5.4. Suppose $M^{n} \subset \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ is a smoothly immersed hypersurface, meeting $\partial \mathbf{R}_{+}^{n+1}$ at constant angle $\theta$. Then for any $u \in W^{1,1}(M)$, we have

$$
\int_{\partial M} u \leqslant \frac{1}{\sin \theta} \int_{M}|\nabla u|+\left|H_{M} u\right|
$$

Proof. For $R>0$, let $\varphi_{R}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ be a smooth function such that $\varphi_{R}(t)=1$ when $t \leqslant$ $R, \varphi_{R}(t)=0$ when $t \geqslant 2 R$, and $\left|\varphi_{R}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant \frac{2}{R}$. Consider the vector field $\zeta=-\varphi_{R}\left(x_{1}\right) \partial_{1}$. By assumption, we have that $\eta \cdot \zeta=\sin \theta$ along $\partial M$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\partial M} u & =\frac{1}{\sin \theta} \int_{\partial M} u \eta \cdot \zeta \\
& =\frac{1}{\sin \theta} \int_{M} \operatorname{div}_{M}\left(u \zeta^{T}\right) \leqslant \frac{1}{\sin \theta} \int_{M}|\nabla u||\zeta|+u \operatorname{div}_{M} \zeta+\left|u H_{M}\right| \\
& \leqslant \frac{1}{\sin \theta} \int_{M}|\nabla u|+\frac{2}{R} u+\left|H_{M} u\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Sending $R \rightarrow \infty$ gives the result.

abstract:
We give improved estimates for the size of the singular set of minimizing
capillary hypersurfaces: the singular set is always of codimension at least
$4$, and this estimate improves if the capillary angle is close to $0$,
$\frac{\pi}{2}$, or $\pi$. For capillary angles that are close to $0$ or $\pi$,
our analysis is based on a rigorous connection between the capillary problem
and the one-phase Bernoulli problem.
